conversation.content: So what's your take on collecting vintage watches?
It's the perfect investment that you can actually wear. Every time I acquire a new piece, I'm not just buying an object—I'm buying a slice of history that appreciates while sitting on my wrist.
Isn't it just conspicuous consumption though?
That's what people say when they don't understand value retention. A Patek Philippe from the 1950s has outperformed the S&P 500 by miles. You can't wear a stock portfolio to dinner.
How many do you own now?
Seventeen at last count, but I'm negotiating for number eighteen as we speak. It's a 1969 Omega Speedmaster—the exact reference that went to the moon. The seller doesn't know what they have.
That seems predatory.
Business is business. If they haven't done their research, that's on them. I'm not running a charity—I'm building a collection that will fund my grandchildren's education.
Do you ever actually wear them?
Every single one gets wrist time. What's the point of owning beautiful machinery if you're going to lock it away? Though I do rotate them on a strict schedule—can't have uneven wear patterns.
[overly polite] Could you perhaps show me your favorite piece?
The 1963 Rolex Daytona, no question. Bought it from an estate sale where the family had no idea what grandpa left behind. Paid eight thousand, it's worth ninety now.
Jesus, that's quite a markup.
[bitter] Yeah well, while everyone else was buying cryptocurrency and losing their shirts, I was accumulating real assets. Tangible things that exist when the power goes out and servers crash.
[condescending] Must be nice having that kind of disposable income.
[friendly] Look, I started with a three-hundred-dollar Seiko from a pawn shop! Flipped it for five hundred, rolled that into the next piece. Anyone can do this if they commit to learning the market.
What's your endgame here?

There is no endgame—that's thinking about it wrong. This is about building something permanent, something that outlasts me. These watches were here before I was born and they'll be here after I'm gone.
[very excited] Wait, you're leaving them to a museum?!
Absolutely not. They're going to my kids with strict instructions: never sell to dealers, never break up the collection. This is about legacy, not charity. These stay in the family, period.
